ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had a live virtual lecture/discussion once a week and then virtual sections on Monday evenings.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really improved my photoshop and illustrator skills. Additionally, forced me to visually describe how I view the city.
This course really challenges the way you think about the natural and built environment. You come away a better thinker and a more adept designer.
Adobe photoshop skills. Drawing and representing vertical and horizontal section cuts. How to produce a graphic novel through story boarding.

So many! This course taught me to think about the limicole realm and consider seemingly mundane objects or concepts at a variety of scales. I learned how to better represent my ideas visually, and developed my own style of storytelling through drawing and other modes of creation. It was also very interesting to learn about how other scholars and creators represent their ideas in a multimedia manner.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really great course, Anthony and the TF's make sure you are prepared for each week.

I appreciated how most of the projects for this course are done weekly or bi-weekly. In previous urbanism courses, the projects were semester-long or month-long, but I really enjoy the chance to dive into something new each week!

Strengths: Very engaging class. The hard work throughout the semester felt rewarding. 

Weaknesses: No real weaknesses for me. The difficult format was sometimes hard but that ended up being a strength.

The course's main strength was the variety and rigor of assignments. Each different assignment contributed to our ability to create a final graphic novel, teaching us many different ways of looking at an environment and its features. We were allowed a great deal of artistic flexibility with each project, which was helpful. Feedback was offered each step of the way. The lectures were also engaging, as were the readings and various films we were assigned over the semester. The course's primary weakness was related to time management and organization. At the beginning of the semester, the workload was quite intense, and while it evened out towards the end, it was a lot to manage in the beginning. Sometimes directions regarding an assignment were unclear, as well, but usually that was figured out. However, overall, the course was enjoyable and helped me to develop many useful skills and new perspectives.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Was able to be successful over zoom, a testament to the teaching team.

Succeeded: Scheduled sections and classes online were successful.

Could be improved: Using Miro the whole semester instead of just towards the middle.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think anyone would benefit from this course, even if you are not an Urban studies/Architecture student.

Yes I would 100% recommend this course to another student. Not only is the teaching team exceptional, but this course really forces students to develop a set of visual tools of analysis and completely pushed me outside of my comfort zone. While the coursework is difficult, each assignment builds on the last, and students are encouraged to be creative. Anthony is a wonderful instructor and I think any Yale student would be lucky to learn from him.

Yes! I would definitely recommend this course. The workload might seem high at first (it is 1.5 credits, after all), but you learn to pace yourself on projects as time goes on. In another sense, it doesn't really feel like work because the projects are a lot of fun. You get to really be creative and innovative in ways that other academic courses don't let you be. For me, the class was a nice balance with my other courses, which involved more traditional methods of readings and paper writing. That said, I don't think I would recommend it to someone who doesn't have a deep interest in urbanism / planning. The students here are really committed to the subject matter, which contributes to a great class community.
Yes, especially those interested in urban studies and design.
I would recommend this course to another student, but only if they are willing to dedicate a lot of time and energy to the assignments.
